docs.lead_paragraph: The board of directors of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest insurer, rejected yesterday a takeover proposal by a coalition of the region's hospitals and the union representing health care employees. The proposal was one of the more novel in New York's ever-shifting health care system. Since December, the hospitals and union have been seeking to take over Empire Blue Cross, arguing that as health care providers, they could focus on managing patients' health more humanely and efficiently than a traditional insurance company.

headline.main: Empire Blue Cross Rejects Takeover Plan

docs.abstract: Board of directors of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest insurer, reject takeover proposal by coalition of region's hospitals and union representing health care employees (M)
docs.snippet: The board of directors of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest insurer, rejected yesterday a takeover proposal by a coalition of the region's hospitals and the union representing health care employees.     The proposal was one...

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans has decided to pull out of the Medicaid program in Connecticut, and state officials said yesterday that they would divide the 33,000 poor people covered by the troubled health maintenance organization among the state's other insurers. The decision in Connecticut is one of the first indications that the financial troubles at Oxford, for months confined to angry unpaid doctors and investors, may be beginning to affect the lives of its policyholders, particularly the poorest ones.
docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans has decided to pull out of Medicaid program in Connecticut and state officials say that they would divide 33,000 poor people covered by troubled health maintenance organization among state's other insurers; decision in Connecticut is one of first indications that financial troubles at Oxford, for months confined to angry unpaid doctors and investors, may be beginning to affect lives of its policyholders; move also raises questions about whether Oxford will continue as part of vast Medicaid program in New York (M)
docs.snippet: Oxford Health Plans has decided to pull out of the Medicaid program in Connecticut, and state officials said yesterday that they would divide the 33,000 poor people covered by the troubled health maintenance organization among the state's other...

docs.lead_paragraph: Norman C. Payson is certainly not in it for the money. When he sold his New Hampshire company, Healthsource Inc., last year, he pocketed some $90 million. And when Dr. Payson, a tireless booster of the medical profession who began his career as a family-practice physician, working on an Indian reservation, stepped down as chief executive of Healthsource, he was essentially throwing in the towel at a struggling managed care company whose costs had climbed out of control.

headline.main: 'True Believer' Hopes To Salvage a Reputation
headline.kicker: SHAKE-UP AT A HEALTH GIANT: THE NEW CHIEF

docs.abstract: Dr Norman C Payson, who recently got $90 million from sale of his struggling Healthsource Inc, is taking over Oxford Health Plans in hope that he can make managed care work; will invest $10 million of own money in Oxford stock (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: For the two million members of Oxford Health Plans, the era of affordable choices among high-quality doctors could change radically under a shake-up announced yesterday to stop the company's financial bleeding. Oxford is getting a new chief executive and a $350 million infusion from outside investors that will give the company some breathing room. But industry consultants and analysts said the steps likely to be taken by Norman C. Payson, 49, the doctor-turned-entrepreneur named to lead the effort, could result in a transformation that moves Oxford away from what historically has distinguished the company in the era of managed care: affordable coverage that offers customers tremendous flexibility in picking a doctor.

headline.main: Oxford Health May Be Facing Deep Changes
headline.kicker: COMPANY REPORTS: SHAKE-UP AT A HEALTH GIANT -- THE STRATEGY

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans sets shake-up in face of financial losses that could radically change company's policy of offering affordable coverage with tremendous flexibility for consumers in picking doctor; names Dr Norman C Payson chief executive; Stephen F Wiggins will step down as chairman, but remain director; William Sullivan, who replaced Wiggins as chief executive, will remain with company; Oxford says Texas Pacific Group will provide $350 million in fresh capital; plans to seek added $350 million in debt financing; map; graphs; table; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FORTY-EIGHT hours after Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos finished helping a big client, John Hancock, advertise during the Winter Olympics, the agency went for the gold, too, by agreeing to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies. The deal was signed yesterday, six weeks after the trade publication Advertising Age reported that Interpublic was ''said to have its eye on'' Hill, Holliday, a midsized Boston-based agency that specializes in clients in fields like financial services, health care and technology.

headline.main: Interpublic Group continues its shopping spree by buying Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

docs.abstract: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos advertising agency agrees to be acquired by Interpublic Group of Companies in pooling-of-interests stock deal; Jack Connors Jr, Hill's sole stockholder and co-founder, says group of 12 executives will share in proceeds; plans to remain chairman and chief executive (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislative leaders from both parties said today that they were determined to pass a bill that would require all insurance companies to cover the cost of prescription birth control, an expense that many women now pay out of their own pockets. Over the last two years, similar legislation has been proposed in Congress and seven other states, with Virginia being the only state to enact a law that requires all employers to be given the option to offer such coverage. But the Connecticut proposal would take things a step further by mandating that reimbursement for such prescriptions be included in virtually all plans.

headline.main: Connecticut Lawmakers Try Again to Force Health Insurers to Pay for Birth Control

docs.abstract: Connecticut legislative leaders from both parties say that they are determined to pass bill that would require all insurance companies to cover cost of prescription birth control, expense that many women now pay out of their own pockets (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Daniel Cohen dazzled the scientific world when his Paris lab roughed out the first comprehensive map of all human chromosomes. This year, Dr. Cohen will complete a far more detailed map and attach it to a tantalizing business proposition: use the map to predict the responses of individual patients to new drugs. The proposition comes with a new buzzword, pharmacogenomics, and the potential to save pharmaceutical companies hundreds of millions of dollars at a clip. That is the amount they can spend developing a potential new drug, only to see it fail because of unexpected side effects or a poor response rate among patients. Dr. Cohen's company, Genset S.A., believes it can improve the odds of success, and reap tens of millions of dollars in fees for the service.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Smoother Road From Lab to Sales; DNA Technique Aims to Predict Whom a Drug Will Benefit

docs.abstract: Human Genome Project, the 15-year global effort to map human genetic code, is spawning new businesses in field of pharmacogenomics that hope to better predict effectiveness and side effects of drugs; such businesses could save drug makers hundreds of millions of dollars in development costs; Dr Daniel Cohen, chief genomics officers at Genset SA, says effort will limit patients' exposure to ineffective or harmful drugs and cut health care costs; critics cite concerns about whether process will work and whether insurers will use data to deny new drugs to some patients; table; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The rescuers of Oxford Health Plans evidently fear that the news from the company may get worse before it gets better. The terms of the rescue, announced yesterday, called for investors led by the Texas Pacific Group to invest $350 million in preferred stock that can be converted to common stock. They could end up owning 22.1 percent of Oxford.

headline.main: Oxford Investors Build In Some Insurance, in Case Things Don't Work Out
headline.kicker: SHAKE-UP AT A HEALTH GIANT: THE RESCUERS

docs.abstract: Analysis of rescue plan for Oxford Health Plans; investors led by Texas Pacific Group will invest $350 million in preferred stock convertible to common stock; will end up owning 22.1 percent of Oxford; conversion price will drop if Oxford's share price slumps over next year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors, hospitals and employers that deal with Oxford Health Plans gave it mixed reviews yesterday as Oxford named a new chief executive, Dr. Norman C. Payson, and announced its latest plans to overcome heavy losses. Most health care experts wished Oxford success, but many worried that financial pressure could undermine the open approach to health care that generated rapid growth and attracted 1.9 million members. People in Oxford's most popular health plans can choose any doctor or hospital, if they pay extra for the privilege.

headline.main: Fears of Higher Premiums and Perhaps Less Choice
headline.kicker: SHAKE-UP AT A HEALTH GIANT: THE REACTION

docs.abstract: Doctors, hospitals and employers that deal with Oxford Health Plans give it mixed reviews; experts fear its financial problems could undermine open approach to health care that spurred its rapid growth; warn of higher premiums and loss of choices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the New York-based leveraged buyout firm, is no longer involved in the effort to inject badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans, the troubled health maintenance organization, people close to the talks said yesterday. Up until yesterday, Kohlberg had been believed to be actively negotiating with Oxford along with another investment firm, Texas Pacific Group, which is now said to be moving ahead with the financing itself. It is not known whether Texas Pacific will invite other partners to help with the financing, the people said.

headline.main: Rescue Plan for Oxford Health Hits Snag

docs.abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co is no longer involved in effort to inject badly needed capital into Oxford Health Plans; Texas Pacific Group is moving ahead with financing; it is not known wither Texas Pacific will invite others to help with financing; 'employment-related' issues with new management that were unresolved ended Kohlberg's involvement (M)
